item.title: Oppo Pad Air 5 Launched With 120Hz Display, Dimensity 7300-Ultra Chip and Huge 10,050 mAh Battery
item.author: Shedrack
item.description: Oppo has officially launched the Pad Air 5 tablet in China, featuring a 12.1-inch 120Hz display, MediaTek Dimensity 7300-Ultra chipset, and a massive 10,050mAh battery.
item.content:encoded:
By: Shedrack

News Update: This article was updated with final specifications and pricing following the official launch on December 25, 2025.

Oppo has officially launched the Oppo Pad Air 5 tablet in China, bringing a compelling mix of a high-refresh-rate display, capable performance, and exceptional battery life to the mid-range tablet segment. The device, which appears to be a rebranded version of the OnePlus Pad Go 2 for the Chinese market, was unveiled on December 25 and is now available for pre-order.

Positioned as a balanced device for entertainment, light productivity, and long-term use, the Pad Air 5 succeeds the Oppo Pad Air 2 and will go on sale starting December 31.

item.title: Apple to Allow iPhone Users in Brazil to Install Apps and Use Payments Outside the App Store
item.author: Shedrack
item.description: Apple Inc. has agreed to settle a long-running antitrust investigation in Brazil by allowing third-party app stores and alternative payment systems on iOS devices in the country.
item.content:encoded:
By: Shedrack

In a significant shift driven by global regulatory pressure, Apple Inc. has agreed to open its iOS ecosystem in Brazil, allowing third-party app stores and alternative payment systems for the first time in the country. The settlement, approved by Brazil's competition watchdog CADE (Administrative Council for Economic Defense) , ends a three-year antitrust investigation that began in 2022.

The move will fundamentally change how millions of Brazilian iPhone users download apps and make in-app purchases, granting them freedoms currently available only in regions like the European Union and Japan. Apple has 105 days to implement the changes, with a potential deadline in early April 2026, which may align with the release of iOS 26.4 .

for Apple to implement the changes in Brazil, or face fines of up to R$150 million (approx. $27 million USD) .

What Will Change for Brazilian iPhone Users?

Under the binding settlement, known as a Term of Commitment to Cease (TCC) , Apple must make several key changes to its iOS and App Store policies in Brazil.

Alternative App Stores Users will be able to install apps from third-party marketplaces, like the AltStore from developer Riley Testut, not just Apple's official App Store.

External Payment Links Developers can link to their own websites for payment processing, bypassing Apple's In-App Purchase system.

Third-Party Payment Options Payment methods from other providers can be offered directly within apps, alongside Apple's own system.

Neutral Warnings Any Apple warnings about using third-party stores or payments must be "written in a neutral and objective way".

Important: The settlement agreement is binding for a period of three years . Apple has stated it will comply but maintains that these changes "will open new privacy and security risks to users".
